storyTitle: As a User, I want to receive notifications for schedule changes to stay informed about my commitments.

functional.title: Verify user receives email and in-app notification when schedule is updated
preconditions: User is registered and logged into the system with valid credentials
User has at least one scheduled appointment in the schedule database
User's email address is verified and active in the system
Notification service is running and operational
User has notification preferences enabled for schedule changes

steps.action: Navigate to the user's schedule management page and select an existing appointment scheduled for tomorrow at 2:00 PM
steps.expectedResult: Appointment details are displayed showing current time as 2:00 PM

steps.action: Click the 'Edit Appointment' button and change the appointment time from 2:00 PM to 3:30 PM
steps.expectedResult: Time picker displays the new time of 3:30 PM

steps.action: Click the 'Save Changes' button to confirm the schedule update
steps.expectedResult: Success message 'Schedule updated successfully' appears in green banner at top of page

steps.action: Check the in-app notification bell icon in the top-right corner of the page within 1 minute
steps.expectedResult: Red notification badge appears on bell icon with count '1', and notification reads 'Your appointment on [date] has been changed from 2:00 PM to 3:30 PM'

steps.action: Open the user's registered email inbox and check for new emails within 1 minute of the schedule change
steps.expectedResult: Email notification received with subject 'Schedule Change Alert' containing details: original time (2:00 PM), new time (3:30 PM), date, and appointment description

postconditions: Appointment time is updated to 3:30 PM in the schedule database
Notification record is created in the notifications table with timestamp and delivery status
User remains logged in and on the schedule management page
Email delivery status is marked as 'sent' in the notification log

functional.title: Verify user can acknowledge receipt of schedule change notification
preconditions: User is logged into the system
User has received at least one unacknowledged schedule change notification
Notification appears in the in-app notification center with unread status
API endpoint /api/notifications/acknowledge is accessible

steps.action: Click on the notification bell icon in the top-right corner of the page
steps.expectedResult: Notification dropdown panel opens displaying list of notifications with the schedule change notification marked as 'Unread' with a blue dot indicator

steps.action: Click on the schedule change notification in the list
steps.expectedResult: Notification expands to show full details including original schedule, new schedule, date, and time of change

steps.action: Click the 'Acknowledge' button at the bottom of the notification
steps.expectedResult: Confirmation message 'Notification acknowledged' appears briefly, blue dot indicator disappears, and notification is marked as 'Read'

steps.action: Close the notification panel and reopen it by clicking the bell icon again
steps.expectedResult: Previously acknowledged notification now appears in 'Read' section without blue dot indicator, notification count on bell icon decreases by 1

postconditions: Notification status is updated to 'acknowledged' in the database with timestamp
Notification no longer appears in unread count
User remains logged in on the current page
Acknowledgment action is logged in the audit trail

functional.title: Verify notification is sent within 1 minute of schedule change detection
preconditions: User is logged into the system

steps.action: Record the current system timestamp before making any changes
steps.expectedResult: Timestamp is recorded as T0 (e.g., 2024-01-15 14:30:00)

steps.expectedResult: Schedule update is saved successfully with confirmation message

steps.action: Immediately record the timestamp when 'Save Changes' button is clicked
steps.expectedResult: Save timestamp is recorded as T1 (e.g., 2024-01-15 14:30:05)

steps.action: Monitor the in-app notification bell icon and record the timestamp when the notification badge appears
steps.expectedResult: Notification badge appears and timestamp T2 is recorded (e.g., 2024-01-15 14:30:45)

steps.action: Check email inbox and record the timestamp of the received email notification
steps.expectedResult: Email notification is received and timestamp T3 is recorded (e.g., 2024-01-15 14:30:50)

steps.expectedResult: Both time differences are less than or equal to 60 seconds, meeting the 1-minute SLA requirement

Draft record is removed or marked as applied

steps.expectedResult: Notification service detects database failure, activates circuit breaker, queues notification requests to message queue without crashing

steps.action: Monitor service health for 5 minutes during outage
steps.expectedResult: Service remains operational, health check endpoint returns degraded status, no memory leaks detected, CPU usage remains stable

steps.action: Restore database connectivity

steps.action: Verify notification delivery from queue

steps.action: Validate notification content integrity and delivery order
steps.expectedResult: All notifications contain correct schedule change data, delivered in chronological order, no duplicate notifications sent

postconditions: All services restored to normal operation
Circuit breaker in closed state
Message queue cleared of pending notifications
MTTR and availability metrics logged for SLO compliance analysis

reliability.title: Circuit Breaker State Transitions and Exponential Backoff Validation Under API Rate Limiting
reliability.description: Validate circuit breaker correctly transitions through closed, open, and half-open states when notification API endpoint experiences rate limiting. Tests retry policy with exponential backoff (initial: 1s, max: 32s, multiplier: 2x) and prevents cascading failures.
preconditions: Notification API endpoint /api/notifications/send operational
Circuit breaker configured with thresholds: failure rate 50%, minimum requests 10, wait duration 60s
Retry policy configured: max attempts 5, exponential backoff 1s-32s
Rate limiting configured at 100 requests/minute
Circuit breaker state monitoring enabled

steps.action: Verify circuit breaker initial state is CLOSED and send 50 notification requests at normal rate (50 req/min)
steps.expectedResult: All 50 requests succeed with 200 OK responses, circuit breaker remains CLOSED, average response time <500ms

steps.action: Inject load: Send 150 notification requests within 1 minute to trigger rate limiting (429 Too Many Requests)
steps.expectedResult: First 100 requests succeed, remaining 50 requests receive 429 responses, retry logic activates with exponential backoff (1s, 2s, 4s, 8s, 16s)

steps.action: Monitor circuit breaker state transition as failure threshold is reached
steps.expectedResult: After 10+ failures within evaluation window, circuit breaker transitions to OPEN state, subsequent requests fail fast without hitting API, error logged: 'Circuit breaker OPEN for notification service'

steps.action: Attempt 10 notification requests while circuit breaker is OPEN
steps.expectedResult: All 10 requests fail immediately with CircuitBreakerOpenException, no API calls made, response time <10ms (fail-fast behavior), requests queued for retry after wait duration

steps.action: Wait for circuit breaker wait duration (60 seconds) to elapse
steps.expectedResult: After 60 seconds, circuit breaker automatically transitions to HALF-OPEN state, logs state transition event

steps.action: Send 5 test notification requests in HALF-OPEN state at controlled rate (10 req/min)
steps.expectedResult: All 5 requests succeed with 200 OK, circuit breaker monitors success rate, after 3 consecutive successes circuit breaker transitions to CLOSED state

steps.action: Validate normal operation resumed: Send 20 notification requests
steps.expectedResult: All 20 requests processed successfully, circuit breaker remains CLOSED, retry backoff counters reset, MTTR = 60 seconds from OPEN to CLOSED transition

postconditions: Circuit breaker in CLOSED state
Rate limiting returned to normal
All queued notifications processed
Retry backoff metrics logged for analysis
Circuit breaker state transition timeline documented
reliability.testData: 235 notification requests (50 baseline + 150 load injection + 10 during OPEN + 5 during HALF-OPEN + 20 recovery), rate limit threshold configuration, circuit breaker threshold parameters
toolsRequired: Circuit breaker library monitoring (Resilience4j, Hystrix dashboard)
Load testing tool (JMeter, Gatling, or k6)
Metrics collection system for retry attempts and backoff intervals
Time-series database for state transition tracking

reliability.title: Multi-Region Failover and Zero-Downtime Notification Delivery During Regional Outage
reliability.description: Validate automatic failover to secondary region when primary region experiences complete outage, ensuring zero notification loss and continuous service availability. Tests RTO ‚â§ 5 minutes, RPO = 0, and 99.99% availability SLO during disaster recovery scenario.
preconditions: Multi-region deployment active (Primary: us-east-1, Secondary: us-west-2)

steps.action: Validate secondary region takeover and notification processing

postconditions: Secondary region operating as primary

Data integrity validated across all notifications
RTO and RPO metrics documented for SLO compliance review
Primary region remains offline for post-mortem analysis

userStoryObject.title: As a User, I want to receive notifications for schedule changes to stay informed about my commitments.
userStoryObject.description:
CONTEXT & BACKGROUND: This story exists to ensure users are promptly informed of any changes to their schedules, reducing the risk of missed appointments. CURRENT STATE: Currently, users rely on manual updates, leading to confusion and missed commitments. DESIRED STATE: Users receive immediate notifications about schedule changes, allowing them to adjust their plans accordingly. KEY FUNCTIONALITY: ‚Ä¢ Automatic detection of schedule changes ‚Ä¢ Immediate notification dispatch via email and in-app alerts ‚Ä¢ User-friendly notification format ‚Ä¢ Ability to view past notifications USER INTERACTION FLOW: 1. User's schedule is updated in the system. 2. System detects the change. 3. Notification is generated and sent to the user. 4. User receives the notification via email and in-app alert. 5. User views the notification and adjusts their schedule if necessary. TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS: ‚Ä¢ Data source: Schedule database ‚Ä¢ Validation rules: Ensure notifications are sent only for confirmed schedule changes ‚Ä¢ API endpoints: /api/notifications/send ‚Ä¢ Security: User authentication required for notification access ‚Ä¢ Performance: Notifications sent within 1 minute of schedule change detection. OUT OF SCOPE: ‚Ä¢ Manual notification processes SUCCESS METRICS: ‚Ä¢ 95% of users report receiving notifications within 1 minute of schedule changes.

Persona: User (User)
